Lets avoid adding anything to the /login API going forward.  This is a new feature, we shouldn't need to add it to every API.  The UI now supports logging in through "normal" Redfish, so we shouldn't really need to update this anymore.
ok, looks like GUI login page still uses /login API, so i have updated /login as well.

The GUI no longer uses /login.  it was moved to SessionService about a month ago:

https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/commit/1ff8e89fd2397c468ab0237158e5aeeff2692413
Done
Lets make this take a std::optional, just so it's clear if the user provided it, or if the user provided an empty string.
agree, will make this change

This doesn’t seem right.  The token provided is just string appended?  Any documentation for this?  That seems like it would have weird behaviors, where if the user attached an OTP at the end of the password, it would be parsed the same.

google pam authenticator support these options like forward_pass, user_first_pass to tell PAM modules how each google-authenticator PAM module can pick corresponding  OTP token for authentication.

https://github.com/google/google-authenticator-libpam?tab=readme-ov-file#try_first_pass--use_first_pass--forward_pass

PAM configuration file will have this configuration
auth required pam_google_authenticator.so forward_pass nullok

That's documented as for:
"Some PAM clients cannot prompt the user for more than just the password."

bmcweb IS the Pam client, so we can implement whatever we want.  We shouldn't need to set forward_pass, we should be able to return both prompts.

Note, that the current logic just assumes that everything is asking for a password.  For OTP, you'd go modify this code here:

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/b729096d0a787abe2a7e8a9a2d1ea12b5e1540fb/include/pam_authenticate.hpp#L36

To handle both an OTP and a password (if it's requested).

I have update pamFunctionConversation() function to handle both Password and OTP.
authentication works with or without TOTP MFA authentication.
but with these pamFunctionConversation() changes, there are changes required for password change operation as well.
Nullptr dereference.  token is a std::optional, it's not guaranteed to be provided by a user.

already addressed Nullptr dereference in latest patchset
but I think its good to take token as  std::optional.
This is a nullptr dereference.  Nowhere do we check if tokenIt == end()
this code is remove
token and token.has_value() are the same thing. This branch can never be hit.
Done

Would you mind helping to review: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69470

It might also help make this code easier to write.

sure will take a look at this commit.
Thank you

I pushed a stack of untested (but code review correct) patches here:

https://github.com/edtanous/bmcweb/tree/token_support

That I think implement most of the code review comments.  Feel free to use them, or come up with your own.

https://github.com/edtanous/bmcweb/tree/token_support

Hi Ed
I looked these changes, looks good but I see pam errors while creating redfish session, I will debug and update this commit
Aug 19 16:50:51 romulus bmcweb[210]: pam_unix(webserver:auth): conversation failed
Aug 19 16:50:51 romulus bmcweb[210]: pam_unix(webserver:auth): auth could not identify password for [root]

There's probably a bug somewhere.  I didn't run it at all.

Ideally we'd have some unit tests, but up to you if you want to add them.
std::nullopt
Ack
std::nullopt
Ack
I suspect we should separate this and make a different one for password change, given that they support different arguments.
yes, I will give a try

There's no array size checks.  If the function conversation returns more than 2 requests, this will overflow.

Also, this is technically a char*[2], not a char**
agreed, i need to work on this code to handle error cases..
Why not an exact match?
Why do we check for either of these strings?  Presumably Google authenticator only asks for one?
yeah, this will asked by PAM module which supports TOTP authentication
Should we make a class with this data to pass in on line 85?  That seems less error prone than an array of char pointers.
